entry.title: Standard bank file format "JP_ZENGINKYO" does not output data in SAP public cloud
entry.content:
Hi experts, 

I used the standard format "JP_ZENGINKYO" to output a bank file, and although the CSV file was created, no data was displayed (except for Kind of record (constant) ).

Using a new format created by copying the standard one and changing the mapping source of some fields, I gained a bank file with some information corresponding to the edited fields. 

I.e.

・Standard format

・Customized format

And some other similarly edited fields. 

The bank file 

Trace result shows that the edited fields received input values, meaning the system can still extract data from master data and payment, but the unedited fields have blank input values, meaning the standard format's sources are not passed with data. 

I came up with an idea that we might need to customize the logic to pass values for these fields. However, in the app "Custom logic", the source of the standard format (table: FPAYHX) is not under CHANGING parameters but IMPORTING parameters, making it not customizable in Fiori launchpad.

Do you have any idea why the sources of the standard format (FPAYHX-REFxx) cannot receive any values? Debugging is not supported in SAP public cloud, so we cannot determine the exact location of the problem. 
Thank you very much.

entry.title: Financial Execution & Claims for Trade Promotions with SAP Revenue Growth Management & SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
1. Bridging the Gap Between Promotion Planning and Financial Accuracy 

Imagine you are a Key Account Manager (KAM) at a leading beverage manufacturer working with a large retail chain. You design various trade promotions (e.g., discounts, displays, rebates) to boost sales and market presence.  

Yet, managing associated trade spends, reconciling retailer claims, and ensuring precise financial settlements can be an operational headache for finance controllers, who play a critical role in overseeing and validating all financial postings related to trade spend, ensuring accuracy, compliance, and accountability throughout the process. Supporting this effort is the Order-to-Cash (O2C) specialist, responsible for managing the end-to-end order process, including order fulfillment, invoicing, and handling claims or disputes related to trade promotions. 

Manual reconciliation, delayed financial clarity, and disconnected systems often hinder teams from accurately measuring promotion effectiveness and revenue impact, ultimately slowing the growth that KAMs and consumer packaged goods (CPG) companies depend on. 

This is where our solution steps in, with its Financial Execution and Claims capabilities that seamlessly bridge trade promotion planning and financial execution with the SAP S/4HANA ecosystem. By connecting promotions planned in SAP Revenue Growth Management directly to financial execution in S/4HANA and then to claims management, we offer a fully automated end-to-end solution for financial posting. 

 

2. A Suite Designed to Integrate and Simplify Trade Spend Execution: SAP Revenue Growth Management 

SAP Revenue Growth Management (REVENUE GROWTH MANAGEMENT) serves as a central platform enabling CPG companies to create, plan, and monitor promotions with built-in integration into SAP S/4HANA’s finance and sales modules. Trade promotion tactics such as discounts, rebates, and display funding are transformed into condition contracts and condition records for pricing within SAP S/4HANA, becoming the foundation for financial execution. 

The execution phase uses these contracts and condition records for pricing during invoicing, ensuring promotions reflect correctly in accounting. Following execution, claims are submitted by retailers for reimbursements or deductions in many different forms and methods. Once these documents and back-up materials are obtained, the claims are matched against the condition contracts. Approved claims trigger settlements, creating credit memos or adjustments that close the loop for accurate revenue recognition.  

This end-to-end integration reduces manual work, prevents errors like overpayments, and offers finance teams full visibility into promotional trade spend obligations. It also empowers KAMs to achieve measurable revenue growth—all operating out-of-the-box within the SAP Business Suite. 

Target integration landscape for financial execution and settlement of trade promotions  

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management. 

 

3. Key Functionalities of Financial Execution and Claims in SAP Revenue Growth Management 

3.1. Variable Discounts Explained   

Variable discounts, also known as OI discounts (can be called either on-invoice or off-invoice depending on the region), are discounts directly applied to the invoice. They happen only during the sell-in process. 

  • Effective Pricing Strategy Enablement

Variable discounts provide KAMs with the agility to implement pricing tactics such as a percentage off the list price or fixed amounts directly on sales invoices. This capability supports strategic selling, such as volume discounts or targeted discounts (e.g., for specific channels, customers, or timing), driving retailer engagement without cumbersome manual interventions.  

  • Direct Invoice Application

Since variable discounts apply at invoice generation (sell-in phase), financial postings are immediate and precise. This direct connection between promotions and invoicing simplifies reconciliation and reduces disputes from the start. 

The precision enabled by variable discounts not only ensures timely and precise financial postings but also guarantees that retailers receive precise invoices, leading to improved retailer satisfaction and stronger business partnerships. 

Trade spend scenarios

3.2. Comprehensive Variable and Fixed Rebates Management  

  • Accrual-Based Rebate Handling

SAP Revenue Growth Management allows setting aside accruals for both variable and fixed rebates. This ensures liabilities are reserved accurately in financial accounts, streamlining budget control.  

  • Variable rebates, also known as bill backs or retroactive rebates in the US, are rebates that vary based on sales or shipment volumes. Variable rebates can apply to all segments of the distribution chain, including sell-in, sell-through, and sell-out. 
  • Fixed rebates, also known as lump sums, such as display fees or feature costs, do not depend on product movements within the distribution chain but remain constant over a promotional period. 

 

  • Support for Rebate Payment Processes

SAP Revenue Growth Management facilitates various payment methods, such as credit memos against accounts receivable, and plans to support accounts payable processes for retailer invoice claims in 2026. This versatility aligns with varying corporate accounting practices and enhances transparency and efficiency in managing trade spend. 

Proper accrual management ensures rebate liabilities are consistently and correctly recognized in financial accounts, enabling compliant and timely accounting postings. This approach builds confidence and efficiency within finance teams, supports KAMs by providing transparent visibility into trade spend, and facilitates appropriate sales revenue recognition. 

 

3.3. End-to-End Claims Management and Settlement 

  • Unified Claim Request Management

All trade-related claims from retailers — whether deduction claims due to short pays or invoice claims requesting reimbursement — are consolidated within RGM Claims Management. This provides a single source of truth with full visibility into claims status, approval workflows, and linkage to financial postings and settlements. 

  • Validation and Workflow

The system supports claim matching to corresponding promotions, with validation rules that reduce manual errors and allow multiple analysts to perform different validations in parallel, enhancing operational efficiency in complex accounts. 

  • Settlement and Financial Transparency (planned for 2026)

Settlement functionality, integrated with SAP S/4HANA condition contracts, will automate the creation of settlement and accounting documents, ensuring accurate financial execution. This upcoming capability will enhance audit compliance and provide clearer visibility into trade spend. 

Ultimately, these capabilities help KAMs and CPG companies deliver smoother processes and have more satisfied retail customers. 

 

4. Co-Innovation: Advancing Financial Execution and Claims Management 

With the Financial Execution and Claims capabilities of SAP Revenue Growth Management, CPG companies benefit from an integrated, fully automated end-to-end financial posting process that links key functions such as variable discounts, variable and fixed rebate management, and unified claims handling.  

This seamless integration facilitates timely financial postings and enhances visibility into trade spending, empowering finance controllers and KAMs throughout the trade promotion lifecycle.  

If you're a finance controller, O2C specialist, or a KAM eager to innovate how promotions translate into accurate financial outcomes and tangible business results, contact us today at RGM_Engage@sap.com to join our co-innovation program. Together, let's shape financial execution and claims with SAP Revenue Growth Management. 

 

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

    • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
    • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management’s Account Plan
    • Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management 
    • Driving Promotion Excellence: Streamlined Creation and Copying with SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Financial Execution & Claims for Trade Promotions with SAP Revenue Growth Management & SAP Cloud ERP

entry.title: Vibe Coding: When AI Writes the Code — Benefits, Challenges, and Guardrails
entry.content:
From my experience leading engineering and delivery teams for high-value projects, I’ve understood that technology changes fast — and the way people leverage technology changes faster. Through the emerging rhythm of ‘Vibe coding’ developers speed up each stage of the SDLC, minimize mundane work, and experiment while maintaining quality. It also helps programmers with intelligent code completions, pre-built templates, and leverage AI suggestions, so thathey can focus more on innovation, complex logic, and architecture. Today, 72% of global organizations use AI in at least one of their business domains. AI utilization is thrilling yet equally unnerving. The potential is remarkable, but it also comes with a huge responsibility. 

So, here’s my take on the opportunities, the risks, and the guidelines every organization needs to consider.

Why ‘Vibe Coding’ Matters Now 

The use cases of AI have grown beyond its specific role to be a significant component of the dev team. Large language models, code generation tools, and specialized AI agents help draft modules, propose optimizations, and auto-generate tests. For enterprises prioritizing data sensitivity, integration, and complexity, this transformation is more than a strategic imperative. It helps change how we define value, delivery velocity, and team dynamics. 

Speaking from my tech leadership experience, I’ve witnessed project schedules accelerate, and prototypes that took weeks to design are completed in a few days. This gave product owners and architects more time to think about long-term goals. However, speed without a structured approach is simply chaos. And that’s where expertise and experience are pressing. 

Opportunities: Velocity, Innovation, and Scale 

There are three big opportunities I often reflect on. 

  • Velocity - AI-powered programming speeds up routine tasks like data-mapping code, unit tests, boilerplate, scaffolding, which further allows engineers to emphasize more on the challenging elements – business rules, edge-cases, and architecture. And for specific implementations, where orchestrations, BAPIs, and connector code are commonly used, code automation can drastically minimize time-to-value. 
  • Innovation – When algorithms manage mundane activities, teams can innovate faster. You must ensure that your product teams improvise on  feature ideas with AI-enabled flow diagrams and mockups, streamlining the feedback process from stakeholders and clients. It’s seamless to experiment when testing a hypothesis becomes more cost-efficient.  
  • Scale – AI helps maintain standardization across extensive codebases and team structures. Trained models automatically recommend uniform code patterns; this keeps your enterprise's ‘coding vibe’ logical and seamless. 

Threat: Complacency, Drift, and Hidden Pitfalls 

However, the flip side also demands attention. 

  • Complacency – This drawback is real. If dev teams start accepting AI results on the surface, bugs emerge. I’ve observed that even the teams with good intentions might push out integration logic or autogenerated SQL that didn’t adhere to data sovereignty standards, edge inputs, and concurrency. These lapses might violate compliance or breach master data integrity. 
  • Drift - Model drift and hallucinations are also the most significant concerns. AI sometimes might generate credible code or documentation that indirectly breaks security standards or business logic. If not checked early, these drifts enter production. 
  • Human Risk – The biggest hidden pitfall is loss of skill. If engineers stop learning basic concepts, like debugging middleware, understanding BAPI contracts, or reading complex ABAP flows, it can erode the organization’s long-term strategic capability. This is a real issue that can be combatted only with a culture of continuous learning. Afterall, AI is here to compliment human abilities, but without human governance and intervention, it cannot make ethicll calls.  

Guidelines: Build for Trust, Not Just Speed 

To experience the strengths while also managing the risks, development teams require an architecture of practice and governance. Drawing from our experience of working on specific projects, here are solid guardrails I would suggest. 

  • Define a ‘Trusted AI Baseline’ 
    Refine prompt libraries and train models using your organization’s secure patterns and best practices. I recommend managing a library of carefully designed model policies and prompt templates in line with your specific integration patterns, security controls, and client SLAs.  
  • Default to Human Supervision  
    Humans should first review every AI-generated modification. For design-based decisions, transfer outputs to product owners for verification against the business results. And for code, combine the AI’s recommendation tools with a named reviewer who has a good know-how of system invariants.  
  • Observability and Provenance 
    Maintain the record of suggestions made by AI, who approved it, and which version/model generated it. This traceability is non-negotiable for continuous improvements, debugging, and audits — particularly for businesses that majorly function under strict compliance demands. 
  • Ongoing Validation: Tests + Contracts 
    Go for automatic test generation alongside AI-based programming. For seamless integrations, you can design contract tests that help define throughput limits, expected error modes, and assert schemas. The automatic tests are like your safety net that lets you speed up while ensuring reliability. 
  • Talent Management 
    Keep your team members' skills honed by conducting frequent in-depth workshops on core topics, switching up team roles and responsibilities, and AI-based training for higher efficiency. We invest in resources for structured learning workflows that integrate AI-powered labs guided by experts. 

How Can You Make it REAL 

Try implementing these principles across different initiatives and collaborations. Some proven strategies I advise using include: 

  • Hybrid Pipelines - Incorporate AI into CI/CD pipelines so that AI-produced outputs prompt the same contract tests, security scans, and static analysis as human-generated code. 
  • Co-Created Models - For long-term clients, continuously refine private models based on anonymized snippets of the code, architecture docs, and integration logs. This helps make AI-powered suggestions aligned to corporate frameworks and context-driven. 
  • Transparent Delivery - Every pull request AI assists or generates needs to be identified, audited, and monitored, streamlining compliance and post-launch maintenance. 
  • Client Workshops - Conduct governance and skills development training sessions that consist of red-team simulation exercises — deliberately coaxing AI toward risky results to train teams to identify and address potential issues. 

The Human Equation 

In the race towards AI-led transformation, the human equation is of utmost importance. Cutting-edge technologies like AI help optimize decisions, analyze data at scale, and automate processes. Still, it is human perspective, ethical oversight, and creativity that unlock the real potential of AI. If you opt for AI-driven innovation, don’t just focus on deploying algorithms—keep your team members in the loop to ensure that teams guide, verify, and apply human context to machine outputs.  

So, by focusing on seamless collaboration between AI and humans, businesses can align speed with responsibility, driving innovation while managing risks. Ultimately, it’s the amalgamation of human governance and AI capabilities that defines long-term evolution. 

Final Takeaway 

I’m optimistic! When powered by knowledge and structured by guardrails, Vibe Coding can revolutionize how dev teams build. It empowers humans to focus on things machines cannot - define objective, map out strategies, and employ critical thinking. The key for quick-moving businesses lies in striking the right balance. 

So, if you’re considering integrating Vibe Coding, begin with pilot projects, capture all data, and keep humans in the loop. Well, the future isn’t humans vs. AI — it’s the seamless collaboration of AI with humans, vibing to design and develop more intelligent systems.

entry.content: Dear Ankit,

entry.title: SAP EWM POSC process (short and crisp)
entry.content:
Hello Colleagues,

Below is a brief information about the setup of POSC process

Configuration - EWM>>Cross process setting>>Warehouse Task>>Define POSC

1. External Storage Process steps - Here we assign the external storage process steps to already defined internal process steps. For example IB01 (unload) is assigned to UNLO

2. Process Oriented Storage Control - Here we above defined external step is assigned to the warehouse. And the source storage type from where the step should be triggered, WPT and destination storage type are assigned. Additionally we can also define the section and bins of the destination storage type 

3. Storage Process Definition - Here we assign the storage process to the warehouse. In addition we aslo assign the direction to it (whether putaway, stock removal or internal process)

3.1 Assign storage process step - In this we assign the external steps (above point 1) to the storage process and warehouse in a sequence as below

The additional columns are auto WT creation (this creates WT automatically once the preceding step is completed), prod/HU warehouse task and the duration in which the task should be completed.

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App Deployment & Lifecycle Management Usi...
entry.content: Deploying and managing a marketplace app using SAP DevOps tools involves streamlining the entire application lifecycle — from development to monitoring — through automation and continuous integration. SAP DevOps integrates tools like SAP Cloud ALM, CI/CD pipelines, and Transport Management System (TMS) to ensure smooth and consistent deployments across environments. Developers can build, test, and release marketplace apps faster using SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery Service, reducing manual intervention and errors. With built-in monitoring and analytics, teams can track performance, detect issues early, and ensure compliance with governance policies. Overall, SAP DevOps enables a reliable, automated, and scalable approach to marketplace app deployment and lifecycle management.

entry.title: Re: DI API: Price Assignment Invalid After Changing Rdr1...
entry.content:
Hi @superpop ,

This is the correct system behavior and it is required to update the document twice.

Kindly refer to SAP KBA 3486918 and 3494796 for similar scenarios.

In SAP Business One client, calculations for Unit Price, Discount % and other fields are event-driven. The fields are calculated and pre-filled before the 'add' button is pressed. Unlike in DI-API or Service Layer, there are no event-driven actions. When changing the list of items and adjusting any price-related properties, the DI-API or Service Layer will execute specific sets of reverse calculation rules to determine linked properties.

Kind regards,

ANKIT CHAUHAN

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: MRP Planning Issue
entry.content: Hi Caetano, In our business scenario, the header material is considered as a dummy material. It is not a physically manufactured or stocked item — its main purpose is to act as a structural element for BOM explosion so that the dependent components can be planned and procured as required. That’s why we have maintained MRP type “ND” (No Planning) for the header material — we don’t want the system to create any planned orders for it. However, we still want the dependent materials to be planned and generate planned orders (for in-house, procurement type “E”) or purchase requisitions (for external procurement, procurement type “F”). For this reason, all dependent components are maintained with MRP type “PD”, allowing the system to plan them automatically once the BOM is exploded. Essentially, the header material is only a technical structure to drive component planning — not a production or inventory-controlled item.

entry.title: Re: How to Monitor Outstanding Liabilities (POs without I...
entry.content: Thank you for the helpful suggestion! I've checked the "Monitor GR/IR Account Reconciliation" (F3302) app and confirmed it works well for tracking **goods received but not yet invoiced** (GR/IR clearing account balances). However, I noticed this app only shows items where **at least GR or IR has been posted**. It doesn't display **POs that haven't had any GR yet**. **My broader requirement is:** To monitor **total future cash outflow**, regardless of invoice registration status, across different procurement scenarios: **For inventory/stock items:** 1. PO issued → GR not posted → IR not posted (not visible in F3302) 2. PO issued → GR posted → IR not posted (visible in F3302) ✓ **For expense/non-stock items (e.g., services, consumables with cost center assignment):** 3. PO issued → No GR process → IR not posted 4. PO issued → No GR process → IR posted → Payment not executed **Follow-up questions:** - Is there a standard Fiori app to view **uninvoiced PO amounts before GR posting** (purchase order commitments) for both stock and non-stock items? - For non-stock purchases with cost center assignment, I understand scope item 2I3 (Predictive Commitment Management) can track commitments - does this also cover the scenario before invoice receipt? - Or is there a consolidated report/app that shows **total outstanding payables** (commitments + GR/IR + open AP) in one view? The business objective is to forecast cash requirements for the upcoming period, so we need visibility into all stages of the procurement-to-pay cycle. Thanks again for your help, and I appreciate any additional guidance!

entry.title: Re: In Group Reporting , Data monitor is used for prepara...
entry.content:
Hello Naga

Group Reporting is used to consolidate all Entity Close data from various companies within the group, hence the term group closing or Consolidation. The Data Monitor is often referred as to Consolidation preparation.

Steps in the Data Monitor contains:  

* The Data Entry Process ( Collecting the data from various Companies)

*  Calculation of Anual Net Income ( that does not come from the Entity Close)

*  Data Validation ( You have Corporate Standards on the Data Quality)

* Adjustment Postings ( These contain correction postings from Entity Close or Standardized Postings to make adjustments to meet Corporate business guidelines)

* Currency Conversion ( Entites deliver data in their reporting currencies, but for Group to Consolidate these data you need to translate it to the Group Currency)

 

Consolidation Monitor

 

Here is where after Consolidation Preparation the Consolidation process starts

Interunit Elimination ( These are transactions that happen in between Companies ) They need to be neutralize cause they do not contribute to the Group Income as for an example and hence need to be taken off 

Consolidation of Investment ( This is where according to the Ownership Structure the Investments get eliminated against Capital and where the Income generated is calculated according to the ownership shares you have in each of the Companies from Group Perspective. 

The straight forward and easy case is if you own 100% of the company, but very likely this is not the case in a lot of large enterprises and hence not all profits are belonging to the group but also then to the minorities, that needs to be eliminated out. 

This is under the nutshell what Group Reporting does I hope this helps

 

BR Mike

entry.title: Control parameter for instant PR creation by saving the Sales Order
entry.content:
Dear Experts, 

i have a doubt regarding PTO process.

With the combination of TAS as item category + CS as schedule line category, i can create an sales order with a material ( even without MRP view )  . By saving this order , a purchase requisite would be created immediately. Yes i know this is a typical 3rd party process. But i am curious, which parameter controls this automatic flow.

I know to enable the whole process we need quite a lot parameters in customizing and material master data, but i am more interested in the immediate action of creating PR. Is this because of the setting in CS (e.g. Ordert type NB ?) , or any setting in TAS,  or even the requirement type on position level in my sales order ( i checked the requirement type is empty ).  ? 

The reason is we may need a similar process to create a one-on-one PR for sales without MRP run, and  we need to create Z category and types to enable that. Thus i need to know which parameter trigger this immdiate creation of PR, so that i can set them correctly at the correct place.  

Thanks in advance!

Regards

entry.title: Re: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 1: Environment Setup
entry.content:
@BharathKumarVaddepalli 

Hi Bharath,

Good question — in most cases, you can reuse the same destination as long as the System URI (base URL) and authentication method are the same for both APIs.

For example, if both your Sales Order and Purchase Order APIs come from the same S/4HANA Cloud tenant (e.g., https://myXXXX-api.s4hana.ondemand.com), you only need one destination. Joule or your app will simply call different API paths under that same base URL.

However, if the APIs belong to different systems (for example, one from S/4HANA Cloud and another from SAP Ariba, or from a different tenant), then you should create separate destinations, since each system has its own URI and credentials.

Hope that clears it up!

— Teng Teng

entry.title: How Job, Org Structure, Position & Employee Info Brew Together!
entry.content:
One of the biggest challenges in HR transformation projects? Explaining the difference between Organizational Structure and Job Structure—and how they connect to an employee.

In a recent workshop, I used simple analogies to make these concepts click for everyone. It sparked great conversations, and now I would love to share those insights with the wider community.

Position: The chair

Each Employee is assigned a position which reports to another Position forming an Org Chart

The chair holds a person, and it can also be vacant

Position sits in the company hierarchy 

Org Structure: Where Your Chair Is

Where the position sits in the company hierarchy (Where the Chair is placed in the Organization)

It’s the map of who reports to whom, which department you belong to, and how the business units are organized.

For example:

  • Business Unit: Corporate
  • Division: Finance
  • Department: Rewards
  • Position: Rewards Manager

Job Structure: What You Do in That Chair

Nature of the work the employee does, regardless of where they sit in the org chart. In our analogy,

So, while your position might be “Rewards Manager,” under “Finance” Division, your job could be “Compensation Expert” under the Family “Human Resource”

  • Function: Human Resource
  • Role: Compensation Expert
  • Tasks: Run the Annual Review Process

Where is it Used?

Org Structure: Reporting lines, budgeting, cost allocation, and workflow routing

Job Structure: Classification, reporting, and analytics e.g., how many people work in HR roles across the company. Used for talent management, succession planning, career paths

The combination of Org and Job Structure together reflects the reality of matrix organizations and cross-functional teams.

How Job, Org Structure, Position & Employee Info Brew Together!

Let’s imagine we’re making a cup of tea — not just any tea, but one that represents how SAP SuccessFactors structures employee data.

Job:

This defines the core ingredients — milk, water, ginger — and the experience required to make it well. In SAP terms, this maps to:

  • Job Code
  • Job Level
  • Pay Grade
  • Pay Range

It’s the blueprint of what the tea (or role) is supposed to be.

Org Structure:

This tells us where the tea belongs in the broader beverage universe:

  • Business Unit: Herbal Hot Drinks
  • Division: Home Made
  • Department: Ginger

It’s how we categorize the tea in our café’s hierarchy.

 

While the Job could classify “Ginger Tea” under the Function “Tea”, as per the given Org Structure, “Ginger Tea” in reporting to the “Herbal” Team. So when Ginger Tea is out of stock, Procurement Team would seek approval from the “Herbal” rather then from the “Tea” Department.

Position: The Actual Cup

This is the specific variant of the tea — say, Ginger Tea with Brown Sugar or Ginger Tea with White Sugar or it could be even without Sugar. It pulls information from the job and org structure, and adds more variant such as:

  • Employee Class
  • Employee Type
  • Standard Weekly Hours
  • FTE (Full-Time Equivalent)

It’s the customized version of the job, ready to be served.

Employee Job Info: The Lemon Twist

Now, when someone drinks this tea (takes the position), they might add a personal touch — like a squeeze of lemon such as:

  • Probation Status
  • Additional employee-specific attributes

It’s the final personalization that makes the tea uniquely theirs.

Summary

So yes — your chair (position) might be in Finance, but your job (function) could be HR. And that’s perfectly okay.

Just like making a cup of ginger tea:

  • The Job — milk, water, ginger, and the skill to brew it.
  • The Org Structure — Herbal Hot Drinks > Home Made > Ginger.
  • The Position is the actual cup with a variant— Ginger Tea with Brown Sugar
  • The Employee Info is the lemon twist — a personal touch

Together, they create a flavourful experience that reflects the flexibility and richness of modern organizations. And in SAP SuccessFactors, understanding this blend helps you serve up accurate data, meaningful analytics, and smooth workflows — just like a well-brewed cup of tea.

entry.title: Re: How Landed Cost works in S/4Hana Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear @FERNANDOCH8,

There is no separate scope for landed cost.

Planned delivery costs (freight, insurance, customs…)  in the PO. Enter planned delivery costs as conditions on the purchase order (e.g., FGW1- freight).

 

At invoice time you can change planned amounts, the system posts them to inventory or price-diff/expense per configuration.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/c370b6531de6b64ce10000000a174cb4.html

Unplanned delivery costs at invoice posting when the supplier invoice arrives, add unexpected charges (extra freight, handling, customs variances) as unplanned delivery costs directly on the invoice.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/634261119fec4d58970471f2c4a9a740/8daa3fa8103347ef9830a8337f69f3bd.html

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3417121

Process for example:

  • Buyer adds freight/customs as planned conditions in Manage Purchase Orders.
  • Warehouse posts GR in Post Goods Receipt for Purchase Order.
  • AP posts the vendor invoice in Create Supplier Invoice – Advanced, entering any unplanned delivery costs; system posts per configuration (distribute vs. separate G/L).

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion
entry.content:
Optimizing DMO Process During SAP S/4HANA Conversion

When performing a system conversion to SAP S/4HANA using the Database Migration Option (DMO) of the Software Update Manager (SUM), minimizing downtime is one of the most critical success factors. This article explains a real-world case study of how downtime was optimized during a large-scale DMO project.

Project Overview

  • Source Database: Oracle, 5 TB (Linux)
  • Target Database: SAP HANA, 1.5 TB (Linux)
  • Objective: Conversion to SAP S/4HANA using DMO (DMOVES4)
  • Focus Area: Table split optimization and downtime reduction

SAP Downtime Optimization App

The SAP Downtime Optimization App proved extremely useful for analyzing and comparing different DMO runs.
After each DMO execution, SUM prompts for uploading the UPGANA.XML file. The app provides a detailed visualization of runtime distribution, helping identify performance bottlenecks and slow-moving tables.

First Conversion Run — Baseline Benchmark

The initial DMO run was performed as a benchmark, using the standard migrate<*>dur.xml configuration file generated by SUM.

However, the downtime exceeded 3 days, primarily due to a long tail in table migration.
SUM (via SAPup) determines this “long tail” when R3load pair utilization drops significantly — meaning a few large tables remain while others complete early, leaving many processes idle.

 

 

 

Observation:

  • Total downtime: ~3 days 2 hours (worst case)
  • Bottleneck: Large tables without proper splitting

 

 

Second Conversion Run — Table Split Optimization

In the second DMO run, we reused the previous migrate<*>dur.xml file and performed manual table splitting for approximately 20 large tables based on SAP Note 3386079 – SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration.

Example of Split Configuration:

SWW_PROPERTIES    segmentsize=0.02 

SRMPROTOCOL       segmentsize=0.01 

/IWFND/L_MET_COL  segmentsize=0.01 

PYD_D_AL          segmentsize=0.01 

SWWCNTP0          segmentsize=0.01 

INDX              segmentsize=0.01 

PPOIX             segmentsize=0.02 

PCL2              segmentsize=0.02 

SXMSCLUP          segmentsize=0.02 

PCL4              segmentsize=0.02 

P2RX_RT           segmentsize=0.02 

BALDAT            segmentsize=0.02 

DBTABLOG          segmentsize=0.02 

SWWLOGHIST        segmentsize=0.02 

COEP              segmentsize=0.02 

PPOPX             segmentsize=0.02 

FMIFIIT           segmentsize=0.02 

FMGLFLEXA         segmentsize=0.02 

SOFFCONT1         segmentsize=0.02

By adjusting segment sizes and applying parallel R3load tuning, we achieved a significant reduction in downtime.

 

 

 

 

 

Key Learnings

  1. Use SAP Downtime Optimization App:
    Continuously analyse each DMO run using UPGANA.XML to identify bottlenecks.
  2. Technical table data clean up.
  3. Update database statistics + oracle database parameter optimizations.
  4. Table Splitting is Critical:
    Manually split large tables based on SAP Notes to balance R3load utilization.
  5. Reuses migrate<*>dur.xml Files:
    Helps SUM optimize load distribution in subsequent runs.
  6. Monitor Long Tail Impact:
    Reduce idle R3load threads by ensuring even data distribution.
  7. Iterative Optimization:
    Multiple DMO test runs yield the best performance tuning results.

Outcome

Through manual table splitting and iterative fine-tuning, we achieved substantial downtime optimization — reducing total conversion downtime from nearly 3 days to under 11 hours.

This practical approach not only enhanced efficiency but also provided valuable insight into how DMO behaves with large datasets, enabling smoother go-lives for future projects.

References

  • SAP Note 3386079 – SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration
  • 936441 - Oracle settings for R3load based system copy
  • 1634908 - Reduce the number of entries from table SOFFCONT1
  • 1918774 - Performance issues when running an SAP Installation
  • SAP Downtime Optimization App

entry.title: What are the major challenges you faced while implementing Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management?
entry.content:
Q: What are the major challenges you faced while implementing Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management in a manufacturing setup?

We’re in the early stages of implementing Microsoft Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management (SCM) in our manufacturing operations, and I’d like to learn from others who have gone through this journey. While Dynamics 365 SCM promises powerful capabilities like automation, predictive analytics, and real-time visibility, the actual implementation process often brings unexpected challenges—especially in complex manufacturing environments.

For those who’ve implemented D365 SCM, what were the biggest obstacles you encountered during or after deployment?

  1. Data Migration: How challenging was it to migrate legacy data from older ERP or MES systems into Dynamics 365 SCM? Were there issues with data consistency or structure?
  2. Customization & Configuration: Did you need to heavily customize workflows, or were the out-of-the-box features sufficient for your manufacturing processes?

It would also be great if you could share some best practices or lessons learned that helped your organization overcome these challenges. For example, did you involve cross-functional teams early in the project, or use Microsoft partners/consultants to streamline the process?

entry.title: Re: Release TR BC initial scope
entry.content:
Dear @Andrea_Gr,

  • Request Has Dependencies means your transport request (TR) can’t be released because it depends on other TRs that must be released (and usually imported) first. This is standard in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (CBC/BC transports).
  • The insert will be lost if you continue is a generic SAP data-loss warning. It appears if you have unsaved inserts/changes in the current screen. If you proceed, those unsaved UI changes are discarded, it doesn’t delete anything already in the TR.

More details in SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3462787

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: SAP Service & Asset Manager 2405 Work Order list Scre...
entry.content:
Hi @DivanWellalage,

MDK by default will apply the entity set property mapped as a filter provided it is single property.
In your case, "Subhead" property of ObjectCell is a concatenation of multiple properties.

If you would like to search by HeaderFunctionLocation value and filter the list, you can follow any one of the below approach

  1. In built option: Map single entity set property like "Subhead": "{{#Property:HeaderFunctionLocation}}
  2. Customer option: Add properties of interest to query builder filter in /SAPAssetManager/Rules/WorkOrders/ListView/WorkOrdersListViewQueryOptionWrapper.js

Example of filtering the list based on entity set properties of your choice from target entity set.

entry.title: Notification for SAP Cloud ALM Feature Approval
entry.content:
Hi Team,

In the implementation for SAP Cloud ALM, when we create Requirement we noticed that when a user request approval to the Requirement there is an automatic email to the approver. Additionally, we can also tag a user in the comment section whereby the approver can be tagged as well.

However, in Feature, we also need to get approval. Having said that, we didn't get any automatic notification to the approver nor we got the comment to tag for the approver. How can we achieve the same notification to the approver for Feature? We had this in ChaRM before in SOLMAN.

 

Kind Regards


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Notification for SAP Cloud ALM Feature Approval
entry.content:
SAP Solution Manager Change Documents has an approval workflow powered by PPF actions using multiple Business Partners and notifications. Different BPs can be assigned to different responsibilities in the CD in the same change. When the relevant BP needs to take action in the Change Document, they are notified by automated e-mails. 

SAP Cloud ALM is not intended as a 1-to-1 replication of SAP Solution Manager functionality. This includes comparing Change Deployment Management (CDM) and Change Request Management (ChaRM) functionality. CDM is a new way of working to manage and deploy code. More information can be found in 3427582.

Currently SAP Cloud ALM Features do not provide an approval workflow. Approval is possible for Production Deployment status only by using the additional Change Manager Role. More information can be found in Role Collection Recommendations. But there are no notifications for this approval. Currently SAP Cloud ALM Features can provide notifications as e-mails in these scenarios:

  • Feature assigned to the user
  • Import component version mismatch errors occurred
  • Transport checks Completed
  • Transport of Copies failed

Requirements and Features are also built with different processes in mind. Features don't provide a comment area. However, Features can be tagged in their "Additional Data" area. You could use a tag to flag it as requiring approval if you want to enforce a bespoke approval process.

If you wish to influence the future development of SAP Cloud ALM and provide direction to our Developers in relation to this topic, please use the options outlined in this KBA 3391676.

entry.title: Re: 🔴 Enterprise in Motion: Event-Driven Architecture Use Cases for Innovation and Agility
entry.content:
Hi @akuller ,

for inbound event consumption, start here in SAP Help: Creating an Event Consumption Model. And/or see the video on YouTube.

At this point I don't see too much value in creating standard (ie. pre-delivered) APIs for event consumption on the S/4HANA core side, i.e. in ABAP. For which events? For the standard events emitted by S/4HANA? The current use cases we're seeing are around non-S/4HANA events, e.g. from Subscription Billing, but not from another S/4HANA system. So the idea of the event consumptionmodel is to let the customer create/generate a tailored API for any event from anywhere - this is possible. And what would you do with a standard event anyway? All we could provide in standard would be a generic receiver that would eventually call a BAdI that would then have to do what you would want it to do. If building an Event Consumption Model is too much effort and a standard API would be better, we have to improve the ECM generation - we're open for feedback, as always. Also, in the end, you don't want a generic consumer, you always want to do something "special", so with that approach the framework we needed to provide would be too ridgid in the end, I'm afraid.
Anyway, check out the ECM.

Cheers, Christoph

entry.title: Re: Authorization in Sales Documents Based on Personnel
entry.content:
Good day @Publiccloud 

Thank you for your description and points raised.

To summarise, the authorisation on transactional objects, which in your scenario is the Sales Orders is not supported through standard authorisation fields in the sales business catalogs delivered in public cloud. The standard restriction framework covers:

  • Organisational attributes such as Sales Organisation, Division, Distribution Channel, etc., and
  • Data privacy constraints based on business roles.

However, individually, user visibility requires a clean-core extensibility workaround because the authorisation catalogues for apps like Manage Sales Orders or Displays Sales Orders do not include the responsible person as restriction fields.

Have a look at the following references and Blog for further details.

Authorization Concept, Authorization Management in Incentive and Sales Force Management, Authorization Concept in BOPF, Business Role – Restriction Field Entity

Blog: Using Restrictions to Enhance User Authorizations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Configuring SAP Business Workflow for parked documents (FIPP)
entry.content:
Hello experts,

during a SAP S/4HANA implementation, we have the requirement for parked document approvals via SAP Business Workflow (object type FIPP). I need advice on the following issue:

So far, I did the configuration in customizing under ‘Make and Check Settings for Document Parking’, I created the workflow variant, assigned company code and defined release approval paths and procedures for parking documents including mentioning needed subworkflow WS51000020 (FIPP_SUBWFN2, two step approval except initiator). Also, I defined users for release authorizations for each approval level in OBWF. Beforehand, I activated the type linkage in transaction SWE2 for workflow framework WS00400032 for event CREATED as well as event linking in transaction OOCU is activated.

When I create a document with transaction FB01 and save it as completed, I check afterward in FBV3 and see the document is not released as expected. When I check workflow -> workflow overview, I see that workflow is not going through as expected. In display workflow log, I check the error message in work item and it says error in workflow customizing for document parking in OBWE. I checked the transaction and related customizing, but I am unable to find the hidden mistake.

Does anyone have an advice on how to solve this issue? Is there anything else to consider?

Thank you in advance for any advice on this matter

Kind regards

entry.content:
Would you please check Note to resolve the issue that you are facing.

entry.title: reservations of BOM components in repair order
entry.content:
hello gurus

my scenario is the following:

we create a repair order based on a sales order, with a FM hence automatically, for a material that has subcomponents (BOM).

in the repair order, only this material appears and therefore, the availability is performed only on the level of this material and not of the BOM components, even if the requirement for these components is triggered.

we want to prevent the release of the order if these sub components are not available: is there a way to do this? if I subject the release to availability, only the main material will be checked and not its components.

has anyone had a case like this or similar?

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud RAP Custom action Print pdf
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG

In summary, once you have created the print action in your RAP Behaviour Definition, the corresponding backend logic is implemented in the Behaviour Implementation Class (<your_behaviour_impl_class>) and not in the CDS entity itself.

The CDS entity (DEFINE ROOT VIEW ENTITY...) only holds structural definitions. It is not responsible for handling the action logic or storing transient content like a PDF binary.

Have a look at the following references and Blog for further details.

Comparing ABAP Restful Application Programming (RAP) model with the Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model, Business Object Implementation Types, ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model

Behavior Extensions, Defining Actions as Part of the Behavior Definition

Simplifying Attachment Downloads in RAP with CDS Views: A Step-by-Step Guide

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Integrate SAP BTP Cloud Logging Service with SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) Using SAML
entry.content:
Dear SAP Cloud Logging users,

We (SAP Cloud Logging team) cross-checked with BTP Security team on the general guidance: SAML and OIDC are both supported protocols. The general guidance to prefer OIDC is/was primarily targeting "Application Users" and not to the entire BTP.

As @shusei_sekiya rightly pointed out, SAP Cloud Logging does not support OIDC for external customers yet. The enablement of OIDC will follow the major version update for OpenSearch to 2.x (phase 3) which is planned for early December. So, the tentative timeline for OIDC would be early next year.

Details can be found is What's new with SAP Cloud Logging section.

Thanks, 
SAP Cloud Logging team

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 Web Client 2508
entry.content:
In 2508 we Choose From List control was introduced.
You can find it here:
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/e060bc9215314528887f925e9b585733.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

it enables multi-selection by setting the property "multiSelection" in the JSON:

"multiSelection": true

In order to process the returned values, the "change" event should be implemented.
I tested successfully the following code:

async onTestMultiSelect(oEnv, oEvent) {
      const value = oEvent.getParameter('value'); // Object with selected items
      const oView = await oEnv.ActiveView();
     
      if (value && typeof value === 'object' && Object.keys(value).length > 0) {
        // Extract item codes from the object structure
        const itemCodes = Object.values(value).map(item => item.value);
        const itemNames = Object.values(value).map(item => `${item.value} - ${item.rowValue.ItemName}`);
       
        const message = `You selected ${itemCodes.length} item(s): ${itemNames.join(' ')}`;
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", message);
       
        // Update the static text display
        const currentData = await oView.getCustomizedData("data");
        currentData.SelectedItems = itemCodes.join(', ');
        await oView.setCustomizedData(currentData, "data");
       
        // Update the CFL control value to show selected items
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue(itemCodes.join(', '));
      } else {
        await oEnv.showMessageBox("Multi-Selection Result", "No items selected");
       
        // Clear the CFL value if nothing selected
        const oCFL = await oView.ChooseFromList("fXbi5iHiSdn2iyMkeyFpgx");
        await oCFL.setValue("");
      }
    }

 You can also use a dialog form as a pop-up form, and design if with any logic you desire.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_ONE_WEB_CLIENT/e6ac71d18c7543828bd4463f77d67ff7/6c4ad8a9fc6748c0a678f1463dea9ffe.html?locale=en-US&version=10.0_SP_2508

entry.title: Business rule for Variable Pay and/or Rewards&Recognition that are using data from custom MDF
entry.content:
Hello,

-> I have the following case for VP. Client has several eligibility conditions for VP, and one of them is looking at the absences of the employees. Since there are struggles in using data from Time Off Module into the the VP and COMP, we have build a custom MDF which will be used by the client to upload the total number of absence days for each employee. Then our idea was to use this MDF in the business rule so that we inlcude in VP (Employee history from EC) only those employees that have a certain amount of absence days in that MDF or don't have any absence days there. However, when I tried to build a business rule (VP scenario) I don't get the expected result, I can't identify which function I should use in the business rule so that rule reads the MDF object correctly.

-> Similar struggle I encountered with the Rewards and Recognition. The case there is that employees who has a disciplinary action in the previous 6 month shouldn't be eligible for SPOT award. In order to store data on those disciplinary actions we have a custom MDF object, and then in the business rule (Rewards and Recognition scenario) I wanted to build the logic to look at the effective date of the disciplinary actions from that MDF, saying that if effective date of the actions is earlier than previous 6 month then employee is eligble, else employee is not eligible (this seems to work), and an additional condition would be OR if employee doesn't have any disciplinary actions then employees is eligible (and this second condition I can't make it work).

Anyone had similar cases maybe, or managed to build a rules using the data from MDF object, that would actually work? Or should I maybe use "Rules for MDF Objects" scenario for the business rule in order to have it functioning properly?

Many thanks!

entry.title: Re: Cannot access F1273 as well as F6748(CBC)
entry.content:
Dear @naoakisaruyama,

For app Automatic Account Determination please check SAP Note. Probably missing business catalogs below in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003073216

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003620455

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/2e2f201d17b346c480bcc2c5610fa0a7.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/53e36b5493804bcdb3f6f14de8b487dd/b362b0a1df3a477eb577c1c71c4d43a4.html

For app Define Financial Statement Versions in Global Hierarchies please check role and catalog in implementation information tab and configuration:

 

 

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F6748')/S35

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Row selection column does not appear in the List Report
entry.content:
@Karthik_Gali 

After adding an action to the behavior definition, you need to add annotations for adding the action button on the table toolbar. Please see the sample below:

@UI.lineItem: [
  {
    type:#FOR_ACTION,
    label: 'Change Criticality (#ActionInLineItem)',
    dataAction: 'changeCriticality',
    position: 10
  }
]
LastChangedAt;

https://github.com/SAP-samples/abap-platform-fiori-feature-showcase/blob/main/03_list_report_content.md#actions-in-toolbar
